newsitem.title: USA: Magazine says Ovtiz having troubles at Disney.
newsitem.headline: Magazine says Ovtiz having troubles at Disney.

text.p: Michael Ovitz, who as head of the talent agency CAA was called Hollywood's most powerful man, is having a hard time settling in as president of the Walt Disney Co., Vanity Fair magazine said Sunday.

In an article by Bryan Burrough and Kim Masters, Ovitz is described as having lost "his aura of omniscience, unlimited power and Zen-like control and (now) is perceived as a confused and diminished figure who is no longer in charge of much of anything."
The authors add, "To hear insiders tell it, he has spent his 15-month reign as president of Disney in a frustrating limbo of bungled personnel moves, strained relationships and wasted time."
One former Disney executive is quoted as saying, "(Ovitz) is in a goddamn snake pit and I don't know how he gets out ot it."

When Disney Chairman Michael Eisner made Ovtiz the company's president, the move was hailed by the film and entertainment industry as a master stroke, especially since MCA had tried under its new owner, Edgar Bronfman Jr., to make Ovtiz its chief but found his asking price too steep.
Vanity Fair said that despite Ovitz's rocky start, few predict his imminent departure.

"Conventional wisdom in the industry now holds that both Eisner and Ovitz have too much at stake to let their partnership founder," the authors said, adding that a recent spate of negative articles about him was producing a blacklash of support.
"The problem for Mike is, this company is in such good shape that there's nothing for him to do," said a long-time associate of Ovitz.
